Literature Review: Turbulent spots have been a subject of intense research in fluid dynamics for over four decades, playing a crucial role in understanding the transition from laminar to turbulent flow. These localized regions of turbulence within an otherwise laminar flow have significant implications for various engineering applications, including aerodynamics, turbomachinery, and hypersonic flight. The study of turbulent spots originated with the seminal work of Emmons in 1951, who first observed and described these phenomena in boundary layer flows. Since then, research has expanded to encompass a wide range of flow configurations, from incompressible flat-plate boundary layers to complex hypersonic flows. One of the key areas of progress has been in understanding the origination and growth of turbulent spots. Marxen and Zaki (2019) conducted a comprehensive study on the formation of turbulent spots in boundary layers, identifying key instability mechanisms that lead to their inception. They found that both linear and nonlinear processes contribute to spot formation, with the relative importance of each mechanism depending on the specific flow conditions. The internal structure and composition of turbulent spots have also been subjects of extensive investigation. Krishnan and Sandham (2006) used direct numerical simulation (DNS) to examine the detailed flow structures within turbulent spots in a supersonic boundary layer. Their results revealed complex vortical structures and highlighted the importance of hairpin vortices in the spot's evolution. Demarcation of turbulent spots from the surrounding laminar flow has been another area of significant research. Cantwell et al. (1978) developed a novel technique for visualizing the boundaries of turbulent spots in a flat-plate boundary layer, which has since been adapted and refined by numerous researchers. More recently, Nolan and Zaki (2013) employed advanced image processing techniques to accurately track spot boundaries in DNS data, providing new insights into spot growth rates and shapes. The growth and spreading of turbulent spots have been extensively studied across various flow configurations. Wu et al. (2017) conducted experiments in a hypersonic boundary layer, revealing that spot growth rates in high-speed flows differ significantly from those in incompressible flows. Their findings have important implications for predicting transition in hypersonic vehicles. Mutual interaction and merging of turbulent spots have also been subjects of interest, particularly in the context of transition prediction. Mayer et al. (2011) investigated spot interactions in a turbine passage flow, demonstrating how the merging of multiple spots can accelerate the transition process in turbomachinery applications. The concept of spot reproduction has gained attention in recent years, with researchers exploring how turbulent spots can generate new spots and sustain the transition process. Wygnanski et al. (1982) proposed a spot reproduction mechanism in boundary layers, which has since been observed and studied in various flow configurations. One of the most significant developments in turbulent spot research has been the discovery of their relevance to fully turbulent flows. Adrian et al. (2000) identified hairpin vortex packets in turbulent boundary layers that bear striking similarities to transitional turbulent spots. This finding has led to the hypothesis that turbulent spots may serve as basic building blocks of wall-bounded turbulence. In pipe flows, recent studies have shed light on the internal dynamics of turbulent spots. Shimizu and Kida (2009) observed a localized regeneration cycle within the frontal section of pipe flow spots, providing new insights into how these structures sustain themselves and potentially split into multiple spots. The self-organization of turbulent spots has also been a topic of recent interest. Lemoult et al. (2016) demonstrated that in plane Couette flow, spots can form regular patterns through long-range interactions, challenging previous notions about the inherently chaotic nature of turbulence. Looking ahead, several promising research directions emerge. Further investigation into the role of turbulent spots in hypersonic flows is crucial for advancing high-speed vehicle design. The potential for controlling spot formation and growth to manipulate transition processes also presents exciting opportunities for flow control applications. Additionally, the connection between transitional turbulent spots and coherent structures in fully turbulent flows warrants deeper exploration. This line of research could lead to unified models of transition and turbulence, bridging the gap between these traditionally separate fields of study. In conclusion, research on turbulent spots has made significant strides over the past four decades, expanding our understanding of transition processes across a wide range of flow configurations. As we continue to unravel the complexities of these fascinating flow structures, new insights are likely to emerge, with far-reaching implications for both fundamental fluid dynamics and practical engineering applications.
